ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A greater awareness about some of the ethical issues that plagues science as well as our responsibility, as scientists, to remain involved and interested in conveying what we do to the public.
I learned a good deal about ethics in neuroscience!
Bioethical questions and how we can discuss through problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: it definitely succeeds at making you aware of ethical issues you wouldn't have otherwise reflected on. No weaknesses.
Great class. I think the TAs should do a little more to moderate the conversation, though.

I think this course is very well made. Any courses that are designed for the graduates (like the Principles of Neuroscience and Bioethics) are superbly good. We had a nice stimulating discussions throughout the semester, trying to identify the ethical conundrums we face in science and how we can partially deal with them. TAs were great, the invited guests were great, Dr. Greer was great.

More emphasis on encouraging students to think outside of the box in the discussions. Several class periods seemed like a rehashing of the same debates that have occurred a thousand times instead of going in new, creative, or innovative directions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yep! If you like ethics... if you like neuroscience, this is for you.
I liked it. Really important discussions.
